title: 106_s2748
content: The Act may be cited as the "Russian-American Trust and Cooperation Act of 2000". The Congress finds that the Russian Federation operates an intelligence facility in Cuba, which has raised concerns about espionage activities directed against the United States. The Russian Federation operates the Lourdes facility in Cuba, leasing it for $100-300 million annually. The facility is the largest operated by Russia outside the former Soviet Union, covering a 28 square-mile area with over 1,500 personnel. The Lourdes facility in Cuba, operated by the Russian Federation, covers a 28 square-mile area with over 1,500 personnel. The base has multiple groups of tracking dishes and its own satellite system used for intercepting communications. The Lourdes facility in Cuba, operated by the Russian Federation, intercepts telephone calls, faxes, and computer communications. The facility has obtained sensitive information about United States military operations in the past. Academic studies highlight the threat posed by the Lourdes espionage station, which collects personal information about the United States. The Lourdes espionage station in Cuba, operated by the Russian Federation, collects personal information about United States citizens and has the capability for cyberwarfare against the United States. The facility's operational significance increased significantly after a directive from Russian President Boris Yeltsin in 1996. The Lourdes facility in Cuba, operated by the Russian Federation, has seen a significant increase in operational significance since a directive from Boris Yeltsin in 1996. The Russian government has reportedly spent over $3 billion on the facility's operation and modernization. Former US officials have confirmed reports on Russian intelligence gathering activities. The Russian Federation has spent over $3 billion on the operation and modernization of the Lourdes facility in Cuba. Former US officials have confirmed reports of Russian expansion and upgrade of the facility. In December 1999, a Russian military delegation visited Cuba to discuss the ongoing operation of the Lourdes facility. The Russian Federation is prohibited from bilateral debt rescheduling and forgiveness. The President is prohibited from rescheduling or forgiving any outstanding bilateral debt owed by the Government of the Russian Federation until certifying to Congress that Russian operations have ceased. The President is prohibited from rescheduling or forgiving any outstanding bilateral debt owed by the Government of the Russian Federation until certifying to Congress that Russian operations have ceased at the intelligence facility in Lourdes, Cuba. The President may waive this requirement with written certification to the relevant committees. The President can waive the prohibition on forgiving Russian debt if it is determined to be in the national interests of the United States, with a detailed explanation required in the written certification to Congress. The President must provide a detailed explanation in a written certification to Congress when waiving the application of subsection (a)(1). The certification may be submitted in classified form if deemed appropriate. Additionally, the President is required to prepare and transmit periodic reports to the Committee on International Relations every 180 days after the initial certification. The President must provide a detailed explanation in a written certification to Congress when waiving the application of subsection (a)(1), which may be submitted in classified form. Every 180 days after the initial certification, the President must prepare and transmit a report to the Committee on International Relations and the Committee on Foreign Relations regarding the extent to which certain requirements are being met. SEC. 4. REPORT ON THE CLOSING OF THE INTELLIGENCE FACILITY AT LOURDES, CUBA. The President must submit a report every 120 days detailing Russia's actions to close the intelligence facility in Lourdes, Cuba to specific committees in Congress. The Government of the Russian Federation is terminating its presence at the intelligence facility in Lourdes, Cuba. Federal departments are verifying this action.
